raw_text:
Mexicans tracking unhappy Juninho
 
 Mexican outfit Red Sharks Veracruz hope to sign Juninho if the Brazilian decides to leave Celtic frustrated at his lack of first-team action.
 
 Their president, Gustavo Parente Sanchez, says Juninho "does not wish to remain in Scottish football anymore". Agent Brian Hassell insists that the 31-year-old Brazilian midfielder is determined to win back his place. "But, if the manager is not going to pick him, that's a different ball game," he told The Sun. "That's something we'd have to look at. Juninho deserves respect. He is not a little kid." Hassell warns that Juninho could reconsider his future at Celtic unless he is given a run of games by the end of the January transfer window.
 
 Juninho was signed from Middlesbrough during the summer, but he has failed to live up to high expectations and has lost his place to 18-year-old Aiden McGeady. "He has 50 caps for Brazil and he's the best signing Celtic ever made," insisted Hassell. "He wants to play for Martin O'Neill, but does Martin O'Neill want to play him? "Juninho is not someone who has come through the Celtic ranks. He deserves much more respect." Sanchez is bullish about his hopes of prising Juninho from the Scottish champions, although Hassell believes Mexico would not be his preferred destination. "We have already spoken with Juninho and he said, if he has no firm offer from a club in Spain, Veracruz will be his destination," Sanchez told his club's official website. Celtic manager O'Neill is no respecter of reputations. "The onus is on Juninho to force his way into the team," he said. "Players get a game on merit. That's the way it has always been and that is certainly the case at Celtic Park."
llama3.2:1b: Mexican outfit Red Sharks Veracruz are interested in signing Brazilian midfielder Juninho if he leaves Celtic, despite his lack of first-team action.
His agent Brian Hassell says Juninho "deserves respect" but believes a run of games by the end of January would change his decision.
Juninho was signed from Middlesbrough and has 50 caps for Brazil, but is reportedly unhappy at Celtic and wants to play for Martin O'Neill, who he thinks would be more likely to give him game time.

Juninho signed with Celtic in summer but has lost his place to Aiden McGeady due to poor form.
Hassell warns that Mexico could be a destination for Juninho if he is not given more game time by the end of January.

Juninho's agent suggests that Mexico could be his preferred destination if he doesn't secure a move in Europe.
The Celtic manager insists players must earn their place in the team based on merit and performance.

Coach Gustavo Parente Sanchez says Juninho "deserves respect" but believes his contract with Celtic is more important than his future at the club.

Juninho has 50 caps for Brazil but lacks a firm offer elsewhere, with Sanchez hinting Veracruz as his preferred destination despite Hassell’s belief that Spain would be his first choice.

"But, if the manager is not going to pick him, that's a different ball game," he told The Sun.
"That's something we'd have to look at.
He is not a little kid."

"He has 50 caps for Brazil and he's the best signing Celtic ever made," insisted Hassell.

Sanchez is bullish about his hopes of prising Juninho from the Scottish champions, although Hassell believes Mexico would not be his preferred destination.

tinyllama:1.1b: Mexican outfit Red Sharks Veracruz are planning to sign Juninho, the Brazilian midfield player who recently joined them during the summer transfer window.
Junior is not currently in their first-team squad, and Red Sharks Veracruz president Gustavo Parentes Sanchez claims that he deserves respect despite Juninho's lack of first-team action so far.
He also warns him to prove his worth or risk losing his place to 18-year-old Aiden McGeady.
Juninho has previously played for Midlestown, but Sanchez believes that he deserves better treatment at Celtic Park.
The club's manager O'Neill is not necessarily against Junior's staying at the Spanish club, as they have had previous talks about his potential move to Veracruz.
However, Juninho does not see himself as a top-level player and has expressed his intentions of seeking a new challenge elsewhere.

The author mentions that Celtic may have a hard time keeping him if they don't receive a suitable offer from another club in Spain or Veracruz.
He also discusses how Mexico would be his preferred destination despite previous statements about Celtic.

Agent Brian Hassell insists that Juninho is determined to regain his place in Scottish football, but only if he receives proper chances and recognition.
However, the new Mexican president, Gustavo Parente Sanchez, has already confirmed his intention of offering Juninho a contract, which could force Celtic to look for another solution.

His agent, Brian Hassell, asserts that Juninho desires regular playing time but acknowledges the manager's potential reluctance to bench him.
Hassell warns that unless Juninho sees consistent game time by January, he may reconsider his future at Celtic.
Juninho, a 50-cap veteran of Brazil and considered one of Celtic's best signings, has been outshone by younger Aiden McGeady.
Despite this, Celtic manager Martin O'Neill emphasizes that players earn their places through merit rather than reputation.
Veracruz president Gustavo Parente Sanchez is confident in securing Juninho's services but expects Mexico as his preferred location.
